s.text: In the first place, the creation of frequent-flyer programs has let the rich get richer, in the sense that customers only reap the benefits of those programs if they fly the same airline each time.

But insofar as dispersing the slots would foster competition, a strong case can be made that it's the former.
The drive to freeze out competition can be seen most obviously in the new mergers and alliances that are shrinking the number of airlines serving any one airport.

The Love Field imbroglio, in fact, has presented the curious spectacle of House Majority Leader Dick Armey arguing that increased competition will threaten the region's economic health, an odd conclusion from Congress' most fervent supporter of free markets.
